Based on the information provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.explanation: Bilateral disc edema in an asymptomatic, healthy woman of child-bearing age with an elevated BMI and normal visual function is highly suggestive of IIH. This patient fits the typical demographic profile, has normal visual acuity and visual fields, and demonstrates significant bilateral optic disc edema as seen in her fundus photos and elevated RNFL thicknesses.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: Which of the following investigations is crucial for this patient presenting with bilateral disc edema?

answers.explanation: Papilledema (as shown in this case) is optic disc edema secondary to elevated intracranial pressure. IIH is one cause of papilledema; however, neuroimaging must be obtained to rule out potential space-occupying lesions. In the absence of intracranial masses, several indirect imaging signs such as transverse sinus stenosis, empty sella, flattening of the posterior globes, and optic nerve sheath distension may suggest intracranial hypertension with a high sensitivity and specificity (1,2). Lumbar puncture demonstrating an elevated opening pressure is required for a definitive diagnosis of IIH; however, in a well patient with normal visual function and otherwise no systemic symptoms, lumbar puncture may be deferred by some clinicians and the patient may be treated presumptively for IIH (3). Often, this requires close monitoring by a neuro-ophthalmologist familiar with following and treating IIH.
